prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We select three lines and leave one window for continuum observations. Our primary goal is to detect N2H+ depletion. Thus, high spectral resolution is not required. The requested spectral resolution 0.1 km/s aim to resolve the Vlsr of N2H+ (1--0) in which we have found the line widths is about 0.5 km/s in Hsieh et al. 2015.

The chosen angular resolution 2 arcsec is about 600 AU at the most distant source DCE 031. This anaular resolution will allow us to detected a N2H+ depletion with a radius of 300 AU. This value is the minima of N2H+ depletion which in a Lint ~ 0.1 Lsun source.

We requsted for 1.19 hours of observing time to observe N2H+ toward 8 sources. The N2H+ brightnes temperatures of the 8 targest are shown in Table 1 and has a range from 1.8 to 2.9 K obtained from our IRAM 30m telescope. (The two sources DCE 018 and 161 located in the south sky were not observed in the 30m survey.) Our requested line width 0.4 is about the line widths detected in the 30m survey and the desired sensitivity of 0.36 K will enable us to detected the faitest object L673-7 with a S/N ratio of 5. Notethat, the intensity is likely to be diluted from the single dish observations. Our sensitivity estimations are thus very conservative.
We selected three CO isotopes for idenfity CO sublimated area toward protostars. The abundances different of these isotopes will enable us to trace both the optically thick and thin regions.
The angular resolution is the same to the proposed N2H+ observations.

We requsted to achive the same sensitivity as N2H+ with a reasonable short observing time hours. We can detect C18O or other CO isotope which have been found to be brighter than N2H+ in our chemical simulation.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe N2H+ (1-0) and C18O (1-0) toward eight Very Low Luminosity Objects (VeLLOs). Our goal is to probe episodic accretion which is used to answer the long-standing Luminosity problem (Kenyon et al. 1990). Episodic accretion models consider that a protostar is at a quiescent accretion status for most of time and accretion bursts occasionally occur to deliver material onto the central star. The accretion luminosity of a protostar undergoing episodic accretion process will vary through an accretion burst. It is difficult to detect a significant variation of luminosity since the timescale for an accretion burst is very short. However, the luminosity variation can be found in the chemical vestige. The N2H+ depleted hole toward a source center can be caused by an increase of luminosity and it can preserves for a long time after the accretion luminosity decay. Therefore, studying N2H+ depletion provides us an opportunity to identify a protostar which has experienced an accretion burst, and explore evidences of episodic accretion process.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy, National Tsing-Hua University

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy, National Tsing-Hua University
